instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2101: What is 820-2101? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V5_SO: What is PP1V5_SO? This is a typo of PP1V5_S0 When you see PP1V5_SO, assume they meant to type PP1V5_S0.
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi,

I'm a total novice at this stuff so please be patient. I took apart a working non-unibody MacBook Pro 15 inch (probably vintage at this point) to reapply the thermal paste and to blow out the dust. When I tried to turn it back on, I got a green light on the charger and the HD spins up, but no fan spin or display.

After investigating, I found that I have all S0 rails except for <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>. As best I can tell from the schematic, the rail should be generated by <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>. I measured voltages around there, and things definitely look a bit off, but I'm not sure what they should be. (I’m not able to measure directly on the chip—instead I’m measuring at a different component, hopefully nearby, but sometimes on the other side of the board. Should I be trying to measure at the chip itself?)

For those measurements, I get:

<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> voltages (clockwise)

[TABLE]
[TR]
[TD]Line Label[/TD]

[TD]Pin Num[/TD]

[TD]Measured On[/TD]

[TD]Voltage[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>[/TD]

[TD]10[/TD]

[TD]<CAPACITOR>C7600</CAPACITOR>, pin 1[/TD]

[TD]4.96[/TD]
[/TR]

[TD]<SIGNAL>P1V5S0_TON</SIGNAL>[/TD]

[TD]2[/TD]

[TD]<RESISTOR>R7619</RESISTOR>, pin 1[/TD]

[TD]Could not measure[/TD]

[TD][/TD]
[/TR]

[TD]0[/TD]
[/TR]

[TD]GND[/TD]

[TD]0[/TD]

[TD]0[/TD]

[TD]11[/TD]

[/TR]

[TD]0[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>[/TD]

[TD]3[/TD]

[TD]L2700, pin 1[/TD]

[TD]0[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]P1V5P1V05S0_PGOOD[/TD]

[TD]6[/TD]

[TD]<CHIP>U7880</CHIP>, pin 1[/TD]

[TD]0[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_DELAY_L</SIGNAL>[/TD]

[TD]1[/TD]

[TD]<CHIP>U7850</CHIP>, pin 4[/TD]

[TD]3.27[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_P1V5S0_V5FILT</SIGNAL>[/TD]

[TD]4[/TD]

[TD]<RESISTOR>R7601</RESISTOR>, pin 2[/TD]

[TD]4.9[/TD]
[/TR]
[/TABLE]
Some of these values look suspicious to me, especially TRIP, TON, and VBST, but I don’t know what they should be.

Also, the problem seems to be intermittent to a point. After measuring these voltages, I was surprised to find that the laptop screen came on the next time I connected the power cord. However, I wasn’t able to get it to happen twice. I wonder if it has something to do with the heat of having the board on for a while as I was taking measurements.

Thanks very much for any guidance at all you can give me!



Greg

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Avoid problem measuring directly on the pins of QFN chips.
Very good idea to use surrounding components as test points.

Check/replace R/<CAPACITOR>C7615</CAPACITOR>.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7610</RESISTOR>/11 are good.
Resolder all components and check traces continuity.

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thank you! I will do this and report back.

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So just to give an update, I was able to remove <CAPACITOR>C7615</CAPACITOR> from the circuit and on my multimeter, it shows an increase in resistance until it hits open line.  I think that means it is working ok.  Should I replace it anyway?  The resistors are still in circuit but I think they are measuring ok.  Measuring across <RESISTOR>R7615</RESISTOR> gave me .9 ohms which I think is close enough to 0.  Measuring across <RESISTOR>R7610</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7611</RESISTOR> both read 5.6kohms which I think shows 2 working 10kohm resistors in parallel.  Would appreciate any other ideas. Otherwise I'll start removing resistors (I'm just not very good ad soldering so I'm trying to minimize how much I have to do.)

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No need to replace components if you know how to test them and are surely good.
Post resistance to ground at L7620; compare reading with similar board.

Remove <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and apply leaded solder on all its pads and board too; then resolder it back.
Do NOT apply power on the board without <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>!!!
Consider to change <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, if symptom persists.

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: On either side of L7620 I get 425 ohms to ground but I have no other board to compare with.  I am working on following your other advice, but I need better equipment and supplies, which I've ordered!

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hi, I measured the resistance to ground on an equivalent part to L7620 on a mid 2010 macbook pro logic board (L7630 on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) and I only got 16 ohms resistance. 16 oms is pretty different than the 425 I measured on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A.  Could this be a source of the problem?

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Totally diferent platform.
Some PCHs can have low reading on that rail.

Post actual voltages of <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>.
Be sure to have good contact between pins and test points choosed to measure voltages.

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
The situation has deteriorated, but I am not giving up yet! First of all, it now seems that <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground. I remeasured on either side of L7620 and I get around 0.4 ohms.  I plan to see if any capacitors on that circuit get hot to see if they should be replaced.  Two more things: The green charger light no longer comes on reliably.  Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.  Also, I let the "magic smoke" out of <TRANSISTOR>Q5315</TRANSISTOR> when I was trying to bridge the power pads and my screwdriver slipped. Oops!

UPDATE: <SIGNAL>PP1V5_SO</SIGNAL> is only shorted to ground when the left IO board is connected at J3400. Could this be the problem? A short on the left IO board?

I've measured the actual voltages on <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>:

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Is already explained on the forum, how to simulate the power button (in safe way).
I don't see why complicate with the tweezer.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

If LIO board is not connected, you can't get Magsafe light; that is normal.

Do you get voltage on any coil now?
If yes, post them...

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thank you.  I will use that method to simulate the power button in the future.  However,  LIO is connected at J6900 and at J3400. I believe only J6900 should be needed for Magsafe light.  But when J3400 is connected L7620 is shorted to ground, when J3400 is not connected, L7620 measures around 400 ohms to ground.

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
J6900 is the power connector.
<SIGNAL>1V5_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> connect with J3400.

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Good news! It boots! The problem was that <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> was shorted within the j3400 cable itself. I noticed that the short was present even if the cable was only hooked up on one side, so I replaced it.

New question: The fans are running at full speed all the time. Is this an SMC problem maybe? This is the reason I took the computer apart in the first place. I thought the fans were blowing because of too much dust, but now I think it must be an SMC issue.

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Run HWMonitor and check reported temps.
LIO board has temp sensor, check the new flex and board connectors.

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Sorry-stupid question. Where do I get HWmonitor? Is it built into MacOS?

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Use Google search engine.
The new installer is known as HWSensors...

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: FYI, the entire first page of results on Google for HWMonitor are for other programs named HWMonitor (for Windows). I would refrain from giving this bad advice in the future.

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>

threads.message: [URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/User:Piernov#How_can_I_read_sensors_on_.3E.<SIGNAL>3D2015_MACS</SIGNAL>.3F.<SIGNAL>2FWHERE_CAN_I_DOWNLOAD_HWSENSORS</SIGNAL>.3F[/URL]

threads.title: Old Macbook Pro 15 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2101</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / A1226, missing <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks very much Piernov. I wish I had known that before I ordered new ones, but live and learn! Regardless, the burned MOSFET doesn't seem to have been essential, as the computer is now working well even without a replacement. The fan problem was caused by my failure to reconnect the GPU temperature sensor.

I'm happy to report that after reconnecting the GPU temperature sensor, the computer is now in good working order. Thank you both for your help and your patience with a beginner!
